It is difficult to measure a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences or those of your immediate family. You may wish to answer them anyway.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1912, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write their answers separately or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 3, entitled "Pioneer Days What They Were Like," is still being circulated. If you have not already answered it, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here.

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing and churchwork
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer family experiences

Preparation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A METHOD OF COLLECTING DATA TO THE PIONEER EXPERIENCE IN SASKATCHEWAN

It is difficult to answer a general questionnaire on Pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has lived in Western Canada before. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience, others may be applicable.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1912, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family has answered the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Board Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Files What I'd Like Answered," will be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
They thought it was a good idea and it proved to be.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
My brother and I took a car of settlers from Snowflake, Man.

Saskatoon for one day and then to Battleford by trail

Prince Albert

Battleford, Prince Albert

They thought it was a good idea and it proved to be my brother shipped a cow of cattle effect from Snowflake, Man.

14. What incidents of the journey west do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences etc.)

At Regina the Railroads were jammed with settlers cars. They moved our car up to where Hanley and left us on a siding for three days. The bridge was washed out but they would not tell the course of the delay.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Saskatoon for one day and then to Battleford by train.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Prince 70 miles north of Battleford.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Battleford, Prince Albert, Prince Albert.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How about you now?

I was employed at Hardwood Furnace and Undertaking Store for 3 years.

19. Locating settlers in Nome district.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Once a month.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

I was married to Williamina Smith of Salt Lake City, Utah, on July 12, 1912.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? It as a place to settle?

Yes - several from Kansas and Illinois.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My sister from Edmonton, Alberta, came in 1908.

My father homesteaded near Salt Lake City in May, 1907.

My mother came in 1906.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would care to relate?

Rafting down the Athabasca and Timiskaming.

From Edmonton to the Red River by Mr. Baillie. We went by train through to Edmonston, then by horse and mule up the Wild River on such adventures. Shawtown, Thaynaboom, etc., and rafting down was a pleasure and real adventure.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? By what means of travel?

I traveled frequently by train, steamboat, and 10 miles by horseback.

Had a river boat and would travel from one town to another by horseback.

Had a steamboat already on the river, which I used for my own pleasure and for others who needed it.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Once a month.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

My brother from Edmonton, Alberta, Canada, came to settle at Salt Lake City, Utah, in 1908.

21. Did anyone else come to Salt Lake City because of your recommendation to be a place to settle?

Yes, several from England and Ireland.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

My father, Alonzo, came by train from Wisconsin to Salt Lake City, Utah, in 1906.

23. In these particular experiences of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which do you like to tell about?

Raising the crops and timber from Edmonton, Alberta, to Salt Lake City.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far?

I traveled frequently by train to Idaho and to visit my brother in New Mexico.

I had heard of Trinity and would love to visit there someday.

35. Did many people move away during the last five years?

No, not this far, but there was a great many from the north that moved to the Midway Park district in the 30s.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were interested in having or doing something in the district, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, post offices, villages, railway stations, creek hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any change in name since the first name was given; (5) data and reason for change.

The Name of Battleford: When the town was built, the word "Battleford" was used. The word "Battleford" was then changed to "Battle River." Hence they called it Battleford.
5. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

There were 3 or 4 Bachelors who moved out of their homes and went to work in the town.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? If so, why?

No, not this year—just three were moved from the north.

That moved to the South Park district in the 30s.
